Someone paid you to write this? Lol, this is one of the bog-standard homework questions in introductory programming courses. Your client is a cheater.

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:11, topic:538366”]guys i wonder…
Whats wrongin having it in the constructor?
i wanna know
thanks[/quote]
Well for one you create a new object every time the input is wrong… In this small example it would have been better to not use OOP at all, and keep everything local to the main method. In larger projects the constructor should only be used to initialize the bare minimum of an object, and all logic should be done elsewhere.

You also could have saved yourself a lot of typing by thinking a little more clearly about the logical steps the program would go through.

Read full topic

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Pwnd:

You should absolutely take all of that out of the constructor.

Agreed. IMO the constructor should just assign the first variable, and then in the kelvin(), etc methods it should check if a value exists for it and if it doesn’t it should calculate the value. There might be a better way to do it though

Read full topic

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Yea I know what mutable and immutable objects are. Im saying that an immutable object is wrong in this case.

http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/151733/if-immutable-objects-are-good-why-do-people-keep-creating-mutable-objects

Moreover, our perception of the real world is inevitably based on mutable objects. When you fill up your car with fuel at the gas station, you perceive it as the same object all along (i.e. its identity is maintained while its state is changing) - not as if the old car with an empty tank got replaced with consecutive new car instances having their tank gradually more and more full. So whenever we are modeling some real-world domain in a program, it is usually more straightforward and easier to implement the domain model using mutable objects to represent real-world entities.

Pretty much what Evil_ is saying. I can’t really think of a situation where temperature should be immutable unless it’s being used as a constant like a temperature requirement, in which case you could just have a final double.

Read full topic

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:6, topic:538366”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=657190.msg4396615#msg4396615 date=1389313924]

[quote author=imthenull link=topic=657190.msg4396594#msg4396594 date=1389309303]

  1. Why are you reading from stdin inside the constructor? That should be done elsewhere, like the main method.
  2. You are using multiple cases for strings in your switch statement, why not just make the string lowercase and drop the extra cases?
  3. Not very OOP (that’s the whole point of classes)

Better example:

[code=java]public final class Temperature {
public static enum Type {
K, F, C // yes that was on purpose
}

private final int k, f, c;

public Temperature(int temp, Type type) {
    switch (type) {
    case K:
        k = temp;
        c = temp - 273;
        f = (c* 1.8 ) + 32;
        break;
    case F:
        // conversion
        break;
    case C:
        // conversion
        break;
    }
}
public int kelvin() { return k; }
public int fahrenheit() { return f; }
public int celsius() { return c; }

}[/code]

Usage:

Temperature t = new Temperature(40, Temperature.Type.F); System.out.println(t.fahrenheit() + "F, " + t.celsius() + "C, " + t.kelvin() + "K");

Overall I give you a 2/10 on the hikscale.
[/quote]You did yours wrong too A temperature shouldn’t really ever be a static value. And technically for a program as simple as this you probably don’t need to create any classes for OOP. But yea, with your example you should have a setTemperature(DOUBLE /not int/ temperature, Type type) and have a temperature double variable for the class. Then you can do the math inside the set temperature method as well.
[/quote]No, in fact it’s not “wrong”, it’s something called immutability, something that I prefer over mutable objects. Yes, the primitive type should have been a double, i wrote the class in the reply box. lol[/quote]When is the temperature EVER immutable though?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:5, topic:538366”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=657190.msg4396594#msg4396594 date=1389309303]

  1. Why are you reading from stdin inside the constructor? That should be done elsewhere, like the main method.
  2. You are using multiple cases for strings in your switch statement, why not just make the string lowercase and drop the extra cases?
  3. Not very OOP (that’s the whole point of classes)

Better example:

[code=java]public final class Temperature {
public static enum Type {
K, F, C // yes that was on purpose
}

private final int k, f, c;

public Temperature(int temp, Type type) {
    switch (type) {
    case K:
        k = temp;
        c = temp - 273;
        f = (c* 1.8 ) + 32;
        break;
    case F:
        // conversion
        break;
    case C:
        // conversion
        break;
    }
}
public int kelvin() { return k; }
public int fahrenheit() { return f; }
public int celsius() { return c; }

}[/code]

Usage:

Temperature t = new Temperature(40, Temperature.Type.F); System.out.println(t.fahrenheit() + "F, " + t.celsius() + "C, " + t.kelvin() + "K");

Overall I give you a 2/10 on the hikscale.
[/quote]You did yours wrong too A temperature shouldn’t really ever be a static value. And technically for a program as simple as this you probably don’t need to create any classes for OOP. But yea, with your example you should have a setTemperature(DOUBLE /not int/ temperature, Type type) and have a temperature double variable for the class. Then you can do the math inside the set temperature method as well.[/quote]No, in fact it’s not “wrong”, it’s something called immutability, something that I prefer over mutable objects. Yes, the primitive type should have been a double, i wrote the class in the reply box. lol

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:3, topic:538366”]1) Why are you reading from stdin inside the constructor? That should be done elsewhere, like the main method.
2) You are using multiple cases for strings in your switch statement, why not just make the string lowercase and drop the extra cases?
3) Not very OOP (that’s the whole point of classes)

Better example:

[code=java]public final class Temperature {
public static enum Type {
K, F, C // yes that was on purpose
}

private final int k, f, c;

public Temperature(int temp, Type type) {
    switch (type) {
    case K:
        k = temp;
        c = temp - 273;
        f = (c* 1.8 ) + 32;
        break;
    case F:
        // conversion
        break;
    case C:
        // conversion
        break;
    }
}
public int kelvin() { return k; }
public int fahrenheit() { return f; }
public int celsius() { return c; }

}[/code]

Usage:

Temperature t = new Temperature(40, Temperature.Type.F); System.out.println(t.fahrenheit() + "F, " + t.celsius() + "C, " + t.kelvin() + "K");

Overall I give you a 2/10 on the hikscale.[/quote]You did yours wrong too A temperature shouldn’t really ever be a static value. And technically for a program as simple as this you probably don’t need to create any classes for OOP. But yea, with your example you should have a setTemperature(DOUBLE /not int/ temperature, Type type) and have a temperature double variable for the class. Then you can do the math inside the set temperature method as well.

item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull

@imthenull wrote:

  1. Why are you reading from stdin inside the constructor? That should be done elsewhere, like the main method.
  2. You are using multiple cases for strings in your switch statement, why not just make the string lowercase and drop the extra cases?
  3. Not very OOP (that’s the whole point of classes)

Better example:

[code=java]public final class Temperature {
public static enum Type {
K, F, C // yes that was on purpose
}

private final int k, f, c;

public Temperature(int temp, Type type) {
    switch (type) {
    case K:
        k = temp;
        c = temp - 273;
        f = (c* 1.8 ) + 32;
        break;
    case F:
        // conversion
        break;
    case C:
        // conversion
        break;
    }
}
public int kelvin() { return k; }
public int fahrenheit() { return f; }
public int celsius() { return c; }

}[/code]

Usage:

Temperature t = new Temperature(40, Temperature.Type.F); System.out.println(t.fahrenheit() + "F, " + t.celsius() + "C, " + t.kelvin() + "K");

Overall I give you a 2/10 on the hikscale.

item.title: Temperature Converter
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

This is a project i made for freelancer, it was supposed to be in a switch…

However here it is

[code=java]package net.euth.freelancer.temperature;

import java.util.Scanner;

/**
*

  • @author Arturo Aguilar
  •     K = C + 273.15

  •     F = C × 9⁄5 + 32

  •     K = (F + 459.67) × 5⁄9

  •     Temperature converter, made this work for freelancer, but im pretty sure i wont get elected haha

  •     anyways here is it..

*/
public class Converter {

/**
 * The result/s will be stored in there
 */
double fahrenheit, celsius, kelvin;

public Converter() {
	
	/**
	 * Prints the usage to the console
	 */
	System.out
			.println("Enter C or c to convert into Fahrenheit and Kelvin");
	System.out.println("Enter F or f to convert into Celsius and Kelvin");
	System.out
			.println("Enter K or k to convert into Celsius and Fahrenheit");

	/**
	 * Starts the scanner (Scans the stuff typed in the console)
	 */
	Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	/**
	 * Reads the input and converts it into a string
	 */
	String input = scanner.nextLine();

	/**
	 * Now we are switching to the inputs
	 */
	switch (input) {
	
	/*
	 * If the input equals c or C, then do the code below
	 */
	case "c":
	case "C":
		
		/**
		 * sends a message in the console asking for the temperature
		 */
		System.out.println("Enter temperature");
		
		/**
		 * Reads the input and stores it as celsius
		 */
		celsius = Double.parseDouble(scanner.nextLine());
		
		/**
		 * Does the farenheit formula
		 */
		fahrenheit = celsius * 9 / 5 + 32;
		
		/**
		 * The kelving formula
		 */
		kelvin = (fahrenheit + 459.67) * 5 / 9;
		
		/**
		 * Prints the fahrenheit result
		 */
		System.out.println("F:" + fahrenheit + "");
		
		/**
		 * Prints the kelvin result
		 */
		System.out.println("K:" + kelvin + "");
		break;
		
		/**
		 * If the input equals f or F then execute the code below4
		 * 
		 */
	case "f":
	case "F":
		
		/**
		 * Asks to enter the temp
		 */
		System.out.println("Enter temperature");
		
		/**
		 * Scans the temp input and stores it in the fahrenheit variable
		 */
		fahrenheit = Double.parseDouble(scanner.nextLine());
		
		/**
		 * The kelvin formula
		 */
		kelvin = (fahrenheit + 459.67) * 5 / 9;
		
		/**
		 * The celsius formula
		 */
		celsius = kelvin - 273.15;
		
		/**
		 * Prints the celsius result
		 */
		System.out.println("C:" + celsius + "");
		
		/**
		 * Prints the kelvin result
		 */
		System.out.println("K:" + kelvin + "");
		break;
		
		/**
		 * If the input equals k or K execute the code below
		 */
	case "k":
	case "K":
		
		/**
		 * Requests the temperature
		 */
		System.out.println("Enter temperature");
		
		/**
		 * Reads the input and stores it in the kelvin variable
		 */
		kelvin = Double.parseDouble(scanner.nextLine());
		
		/**
		 * The celsius formula
		 */
		celsius = kelvin - 273.15;
		
		/**
		 * The fahrenheit formula
		 */
		fahrenheit =  celsius * 9/5 + 32;
		
		/**
		 * Prints the celsius result
		 */
		System.out.println("C:" + celsius + "");
		
		/**
		 * Prints the fahrenheit result
		 */
		System.out.println("F:" + fahrenheit + "");
		break;
		
		/**
		 * In case it wasn't any of them, call the method again
		 */
	 default:
		 
		 /**
		  * message to the console saying to try again
		  */
		 System.out.println("Your input was wrong, try again");
		 
		 /**
		  * Calls the method again
		  */
		 Converter converter = new Converter();
		break;
	}
}

public static void main(String args[]) {
	/**
	 * Instances the constructor 
	 */
	Converter converter = new Converter();
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic
